#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Boston/Downtown
#Text=Downtown
#Text=Boston is really the heart of the city .
#Text=Boston City Hall is here , and many powerful companies and agencies are headquartered in the area .
#Text=Since urban planning was done here before the advent of the automobile , this area of town has secured a decidedly European flavor .
#Text=Here you 'll find pedestrian focused streets , large public green spaces , street performers , and historic sites all connected by an efficient public transit system .
#Text=If you 're looking for the adjacent Italian American neighborhood with great food , head on over to the North End .
#Text=If you want nearby Boston Common and the State House instead , start exploring Back Bay & Beacon Hill .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Boston 's nickname as the " Hub " makes more sense once you visit downtown .
#Text=The population balloons during the day as hundreds of thousands of office workers and tourists descend on the area .
#Text=The Massachusetts State Government maintains its seat in nearby Beacon Hill , but most state employees work out of office buildings around Government Center , where City Hall is also located .
#Text=Downtown is home to major shopping areas , many of Boston 's most famous historic sites , and plenty of major private employers .
#Text=The financial and legal industry in the city is still largely based here , although some have decamped to nicer and newer space in the Seaport .
#Text=The area now known as Downtown used to comprise most of the City of Boston , aside from the North End and Beacon Hill .
#Text=Places like Charlestown and Dorchester were originally separate towns .

#Text=Boston was founded in 1628 on a head of land sticking out into the harbor , connected to the mainland only by a thin strip of land which is today called Washington St. Other Boston neighborhoods were created through filling in marshland or annexing neighboring towns .
#Text=Boston was a hotbed of the American Revolution , being home to now famous patriots like John Adams , Sam Adams , and John Hancock .
#Text=Important pre-revolutionary events like the Boston Tea Party and Boston Massacre happened in what is now Downtown .
#Text=After the war , Boston continued to be an important seaport and trading center .
#Text=Until the 1860s and 70s , Downtown was pretty much all there was to the city .
#Text=During this period , it expanded dramatically and outgrew its old borders , but Downtown remained the hub , although it is one of the northernmost parts of the city .
#Text=Much of Downtown burned down in the Great Fire of 1872 , tragically taking some of the city 's older buildings with it .
#Text=This area is now the main financial district and is mostly modern skyscrapers .
#Text=In the 1950s the Central Artery , an elevated highway , was built through downtown , cutting off the waterfront from the rest of downtown .
#Text=At a cost of $ 15 billion , it was buried during the " Big Dig " in the 1990s and early 2000s and Downtown is now reunited with its waterfront .
#Text=Chinatown
#Text=Chinatown was built on a landfill , though this is no longer apparent ; what now identifies this area is the truly mixed uses of land .
#Text=Residential properties co-exist with family owned and operated businesses and local institutions .
#Text=Bay Village
#Text=One of the smallest neighborhoods in Boston , about 6 square blocks around Piedmont Street east of Arlington .

#Text=After the original mud flats were drained in the early 1800s , many craftsmen involved in the construction of Beacon Hill 's premier residences built their own modest but well-crafted houses here .
#Text=Consequently , there are many architectural similarities between these two neighborhoods .
#Text=It was n't until the Prohibition years ( 1920s ) that Bay Village got its bohemian ambiance .
#Text=It has now become the center for Boston 's gay community .
#Text=Leather District

#Text=Bounded by Chinatown to the west , South Station to the east , the Financial District to the north , and Kneeland Street to the south , this neighborhood was the home of leather production and sales during the 19th century .
#Text=It consists of a series of buildings constructed in the Classic Revival and Romanesque styles , largely between 1880 and 1920 .
#Text=Visually similar to SoHo , New York , it has been used for numerous films and advertisements as a stand-in location .
#Text=The Leather District is a mixed use community , home to loft apartments , ramen joints , and French bistros .
#Text=The As South Station , a major bus , commuter rail , train , and subway terminal , defines its eastern boundary , it is often visited by people entering or exiting the city .
#Text=By foot
#Text=Walking is by far the preferred way to get around this area , as most everything you 'd want to see is relatively packed in together .
#Text=The train stations are usually only separated by a few minutes walk , and you 'll find it 's often faster to just walk directly to your destination without heading underground .
#Text=Walking also affords the opportunity to explore the variety of urban parks , architecture , and quirky street patterns that have gracefully developed over time .
#Text=Walking around downtown is in many ways what visitors come here to experience in the first place .
#Text=By public transit
#Text=Downtown is easily the best connected area in the city .
#Text=Boston operates on a " hub and spoke " philosophy , and this is clearly the hub for a variety of modes of transport .
#Text=Amtrak makes two stops here , the massive South Station offers connections to NYC , Chicago , and beyond .
#Text=Also featuring rail connections is North Station , serving coastal points within Maine and New Hampshire .
#Text=See Boston#By train for details .
#Text=These two stations are also the termini for all Commuter Rail travel within the region , see Boston#By commuter rail for more detailed descriptions .
#Text=By subway
#Text=The Green line is perhaps the most helpful for visitors , running close to much of the Freedom Trail and the North End .
#Text=Stops include North Station , Haymarket , Government Center , Park Street , and Boylston .
#Text=The Orange line is a great alternative , because it closely parallels the Green line while downtown .
#Text=Stations include : North Station , Haymarket , State , Downtown Crossing , Chinatown , and Tufts Medical Center .
#Text=The Red line is also quite popular , if you 're near it , it can be great for getting across town .
#Text=Red stops include : Charles/MGH , Park Street , Downtown Crossing and South Station along the way .
#Text=The Blue line is good for getting to the Aquarium , but it is primarily used by residents and not tourists .
#Text=This line begins at tiny Bowdoin , then visits Government Center , State , and Aquarium stations before diving under the harbor .
#Text=Almost every station downtown serves more than one line , and transferring between them is quick and painless .
#Text=Walking between the Green , Orange , and Red lines is pretty easy , an underground walkway connects Park Street and Downtown Crossing stations .
#Text=Much to the displeasure of Bostonians , there is no direct connection between North and South Station .
#Text=It can take 20-30 minutes to transfer between the two , so take that ( along with your luggage ) into account .
#Text=You 'll also find the Blue and Red lines are similarly disconnected , and will need to use the Orange or Green lines to transfer between them .
